Georgian officials said that [[Baku–Tbilisi–Ceyhan pipeline]] was attacked by Russian planes that day, but was not damaged.<ref name="churkin_third_refusal"/><ref name="all-out_war"/> At least five Georgian cities had been bombed by Russia by 9 August.<ref name="all-out_war"/>
Georgian president Saakashvili had said in an interview on CNN, "We are willing to do cease-fire immediately providing the other side stops to shoot and to bomb." However, the Kremlin press office claimed that Russia did not receive any official offer of a cease-fire.<ref name="bloomberg steam"/>
CNN described Russian deployment to South Ossetia on 9 August, "Dozens of columns of up to 40 exhaust-belching vehicles wound through long tunnels, crossed bridges and passed villages clinging to the steep mountain slopes."<ref name="cnn_dozens"/> According to Associated Press, it was the entry of Russian tanks and bombing of Georgian town that escalated the conflict.<ref name="churkin_third_refusal"/>
=== August 10 === [[File:T813 army2.JPG|thumb|A Czech [[RM-70 Multiple rocket launcher|RM-70]] [[multiple rocket launcher]]. Similar RM-70s were used by Georgia during the war in the [[Battle of Tskhinvali]].]] [[File:Tbilisi-2008-08-10.jpg|thumb|Georgian refugees from South Ossetia beg the Georgian Parliament for help.]]
Reuters reported that South Ossetian officials claimed that fighting on the southern outskirts of Tskhinvali had ended at about midnight.<ref name="Russian general wounded in Georgia's rebel region">{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/europeCrisis/idUSL9494498 |title=Russian general wounded in Georgia's rebel region |publisher=Reuters |date=9 August 2008 | first=Dmitry | last=Solovyov}}</ref> According to South Ossetia, 12 Georgian tanks were destroyed on the outskirts of Tskhinvali.<ref name="churkin_third_refusal"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://eng.kavkaz-uzel.ru/newstext/engnews/id/1226981.html |title=Georgian tanks and infantry invade Tskhinvali |publisher=Caucasian Knot |date=10 August 2008}}</ref>
Alexander Lomaya, Secretary of National Security Council of Georgia, had said conflict began because Russia aimed to "thwart its neighbors’ movement toward Western society and Western values", adding "If the world is not able to stop Russia here, then Russian tanks and Russian paratroopers can appear in every European capital." Georgian officials admitted that Russian reaction surprised them. ''The New York Times'' stated that Russia "appeared determined to occupy both South Ossetia and Abkhazia." ''The New York Times'' reported that Georgian President Saakashvili had said that Georgia was in a state of war and Russia planned to occupy strategic economic infrastructure and to depose his government. However, when Anatoly Nogovitsyn, colonel general in the Russian Ministry of Defense, was asked whether Russia was in a state of war, he replied that was not the case. Georgian health minister had said that Georgian casualties were more than 80, 40 of which were civilians killed in the bombing of Gori. Georgian officials had said the conflict would end if the United States intervened, however they were counting on the Western diplomatic outcry to impact Russia.<ref name="all-out_war"/>
After his visit to North Ossetia, Putin paid a visit to the [[Gorki Leninskiye|Gorki]] residence near Moscow to meet Russian president Medvedev on early 10 August. There he called on the Prosecutor General's Office to investigate Georgian military action.<ref name="churkin_third_refusal">{{cite news|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5hV2N6fVKS5slf10A13Dj_uIdaZ4QD92F7IOG0| title=Georgia: In 'state of war' over South Ossetia|publisher=Associated Press|date=10 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080811174947/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5hV2N6fVKS5slf10A13Dj_uIdaZ4QD92F7IOG0 |archivedate=11 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=October 2012|bot=Legobot}}</ref><ref name="bloomberg steam"/> Earlier in Vladikavkaz, Putin had named Georgian military action "complete genocide."<ref name="expands_blitz"/> Later that day, Medvedev stated, "There should be no doubt that the operation to force Georgia to peace will continue and the guilty ones will be brought to account." He ordered an investigation into acts of "genocide" committed by Georgia and suggested an international tribunal.<ref name="complete genocide">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-international/medvedev-putin-accuse-georgia-of-genocide/article1314526.ece | title=Medvedev, Putin accuse Georgia of genocide | publisher=The Hindu| date=11 August 2008}}</ref>
A ceasefire to begin at 05:00 was ordered by Georgian president Saakashvili.<ref name="ceasefire_ordered_5am"/>
The Georgian Interior Ministry stated that 6,000 Russian soldiers had entered Georgia by land and another 4,000 were moved by sea.<ref name="alertnet mass">{{cite news |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LA423150.htm |title=Russian forces mass against Georgia, says official |publisher=Reuters AlertNet |date=10 August 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080812114255/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LA423150.htm |archivedate=12 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> Georgian Interior Ministry said before the dawn that military facilities near the civilian airport at Tbilisi were being bombed and people in Tbilisi could hear the explosions.<ref name="all-out_war"/>
''Lenta.ru'' reported that on the morning of 10 August, several Russian warships arrived at one of the ports of Abkhazia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/08/10/sank/|script-title=ru:Российские корабли потопили грузинский ракетный катер|date=11 August 2008 |publisher=Lenta.ru|language=ru}}</ref> The West had been earlier warned by Russia that the Black Sea fleet warships were sent to [[Ochamchire]] in Abkhazia.<ref name="all-out_war"/> Georgian official reported that Russian warship from the Black Sea fleet barred a cargo ship from entering Poti, thus blockading the Georgian coast. Another Georgian official, Kakha Lomaia, stated that Russian jets simultaneously had bombed military and civilian targets in six locations. Lomaia stated that at least 55 Georgians were killed.<ref name="bloomberg steam"/> Russian media claimed on 10 August that Russia was preparing to blockade the Georgian coast.<ref name="smh_10aug"/><ref name="expands_blitz"/>
[[File:Kekhvi on fire.jpg|thumb|right|A house set on fire burns in the Georgian village of [[Kekhvi]] on the road from Tskhinvali to Java.]]
Georgia’s Internal Affairs Ministry spokesman, Shota Utiashvili, said that "Georgian troops have fully left South Ossetia", while according to [[Kakha Lomaia]], Georgian troops "have relocated and assumed new positions." Russian peacekeeping force's spokesman Vladimir Ivanov, however, stated that "Georgia did not remove its forces from South Ossetia. Our observation posts have spotted Georgian law-enforcement units, as well as artillery and armoured vehicles."<ref name="yahoo russia observation">{{cite news |url=http://in.news.yahoo.com/20/20080810/1422/twl-georgia-says-its-troops-have-left-s.html |title=Georgia says its troops 'have left S Ossetia' |publisher=Yahoo News India |date=10 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080818115412/http://in.news.yahoo.com/20/20080810/1422/twl-georgia-says-its-troops-have-left-s.html |archivedate=18 August 2008}}{{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Utiashvili told the BBC that Georgians withdrew to positions of 6 August because of "humanitarian catastrophe".<ref name="bbc pullout"/> Although Georgia had said it had pulled out most its forces from South Ossetia, Russian officials stated that day that Georgia still had about 7,400 troops, 100 tanks and artillery in South Ossetia. It was reported that "Georgia's army of less than 25,000 men is confronting a Russian force which can count on more than one million troops."<ref name="smh_10aug"/> Colonel-General Anatoly Nogovitsyn of the Russian General Staff declared on the same day that "most of the city [Tskhinvali] is controlled by Russian peacekeeping forces." However, the fighting was still underway in Tskhinvali on late 10 August. Later that day, a dwindle in the fighting was reported by the South Ossetians.<ref name="ceasefire_ordered_5am">{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/aug/10/georgia.russia1?gusrc=rss&feed=networkfront |title=Russia takes control of South Ossetian capital after Georgian retreat |publisher=The Guardian |date=10 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/08/11/again/|script-title=ru:Цхинвали вновь подвергся артиллерийскому обстрелу|publisher=Lenta.ru|date=11 August 2008|language=Russian}}</ref>
[[President of Abkhazia]] [[Sergei Bagapsh]] said 1,000 troops were sent to the [[Kodori Valley]]. The mobilisation of reservists to reinforce positions was announced by him. He warned Abkhazia was ready to "enforce order" and would push further in case of Georgian resistance.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/europeCrisis/idUSLA578672|title=Georgia rebel region sends troops to disputed gorge|publisher=Reuters|date=10 August 2008}}</ref> That day, it was reported that separatist military was also concentrating on the border of [[Zugdidi Municipality]].<ref name="expands_blitz"/> On the same day, Abkhaz president also accused Georgia of "genocide". That day, Russia was accused of having sent 150 tanks and 10 thousand troops to Abkhazia by Georgian president Saakashvili.<ref name="ceasefire_ordered_5am"/>
South Ossetian authorities had stated that 20 were killed and 150 wounded in Tskhinvali after overnight shelling. That day, Georgian Reintegration Minister Temur Iakobashvili said that the city of Zugdidi in western Georgia was being bombed.<ref name="smh_10aug">{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/russia-seizes-south-ossetia-as-wider-conflict-feared-20080810-3t3l.html |title=Russia seizes South Ossetia as wider conflict feared |publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=10 August 2008}}</ref><!--http://www.boerevryheid.co.za/forums/showthread.php?12571-Kan-dit-die-begin-van-die-Derde-wereldoorlog-wees&p=200521&viewfull=1#post200521 5:03 PM Georgia local time--><ref name="bbc pullout">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7552012.stm |title=Georgia 'pulls out of S Ossetia' |publisher=BBC News |date=10 August 2008}}</ref>
The Foreign Ministry of Georgia announced readiness to negotiate a ceasefire and said that it had warned Russian diplomatic representative to Georgia. However, Russians claimed Georgian forces were not retreating, but merely regrouping. Georgian official stated that its forces were forced to retreat from South Ossetia.<!--"Georgia says it was responding to attacks by separatists. In response, Russia launched massive artillery shelling and air attacks on Georgian troops."--><ref name="expands_blitz">{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20080810/ap_on_re_eu/georgia_south_ossetia|title=Russia expands Georgia blitz, deploys ships |date=10 August 2008 |publisher=Associated Press |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080811225805/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20080810/ap_on_re_eu/georgia_south_ossetia|archivedate=11 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> Russian Foreign Ministry confirmed receiving the offer, but said that "the Georgian side has not stopped military actions in South Ossetia, Georgian troops continued shelling."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interfax.ru/news.asp?id=26320|script-title=ru:Грузия пока не прекратила огонь|date=10 August 2008 |publisher=Interfax|language=ru}}</ref> That day, the withdrawal of some Georgian troops was confirmed by deputy chief of the Russian General Staff, Colonel General [[Anatoliy Nogovitsyn]]. He said as many Russian troops would be sent to South Ossetia "as the situation may require," but they would not enter Georgia. Russian deputy Foreign Minister [[Grigory Karasin]] ruled out peace talks with Georgia until the latter withdrew from South Ossetia and signed a legally binding pact against the use of force against South Ossetia and Abkhazia.<ref name="hindu1">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/georgia-pulls-out-forces/article1314035.ece |title=Georgia pulls out forces |publisher=The Hindu |date=11 August 2008}}</ref>
Georgia and a Reuters witness reported that [[Tbilisi International Airport]] was the target of a Russian air strike, just a few hours before the scheduled arrival of French Foreign Minister [[Bernard Kouchner]]. Construction plant near to the airport was also bombed.<ref name="reuters1">{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSLA548281 |title=Tbilisi civilian airport hit in Russian air strike |publisher=Reuters |date=10 August 2008}}</ref> According to Georgian authorities, three bombs had been dropped on the site that day.<ref name="bbc pullout"/> The Russian Ministry of Defence dismissed this report as "informational provocation" by Georgia.<ref name="newsru1">{{cite web|url=http://palm.newsru.com/world/10aug2008/atacka2.html|script-title=ru:МВД Грузии сообщает об ударе российской авиации по тбилисскому аэропорту, минобороны России упрекает его в "информационных провокациях"|publisher=NEWSru.com|date=10 August 2008|language=ru}}</ref> Georgian State Minister for Reintegration, Temur Iakobashvili later stated, "There was no attack on the airport in Tbilisi. It was a factory that produces combat airplanes."<ref>{{cite news|title=Jewish Georgian minister: Thanks to Israeli training, we're fending off Russia|url=http://www.khilafah.com/index.php/news-watch/middle-east/3400-jewish-georgian-minister-thanks-to-israeli-training-were-fending-off-russia|publisher=Khilafah|date=11 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110221182050/http://www.khilafah.com/index.php/news-watch/middle-east/3400-jewish-georgian-minister-thanks-to-israeli-training-were-fending-off-russia|archivedate=21 February 2011}}</ref>
A session of the [[United Nations Security Council]] was convened, in which UN Under-Secretary-General [[B. Lynn Pascoe]] gave a briefing about the refugee situation and [[Edmond Mulet]] briefed about the situation relating to the mandate of [[UNOMIG]].<ref name="meeting_5953">{{cite web|url=http://www.undemocracy.com/securitycouncil/meeting_5953 |title=Security Council meeting 5953 |publisher=UNdemocracy |date=10 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821003812/http://www.undemocracy.com/securitycouncil/meeting_5953 |archivedate=21 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> Following statements by Georgia and the United States, the Russian ambassador said: "Unfortunately, I have to point out that the content of the briefing by Mr. Pascoe shows that the Secretariat and its leadership have not been able to adopt an objective position showing a thorough grasp of the substance of this conflict, as should be expected from the leadership of such an authoritative international organization."<ref name="meeting_5953"/> The Ambassador for the United States stated: "Foreign Minister Lavrov told United States Secretary of State Rice that the democratically elected President of Georgia — and I quote — 'must go'. I quote again: 'Saakashvili must go'. This is completely unacceptable and crosses the line."<ref name="meeting_5953"/> The Russian ambassador responded by saying, "On Ambassador Khalilzad’s interesting reference to a confidential diplomatic telephone call between our Minister for Foreign Affairs and his Secretary of State, I must say at the outset that regime change is an American expression. We do not use such expressions."<ref name="meeting_5953"/> After the meeting, CNN reported, "But Churkin drew a rebuke from other Security Council members, including its current president, after he questioned the objectivity of a top U.N. official who briefed ambassadors on the conflict in Georgia".<ref name="UN0810EmerSess">{{cite news| title=U.S.: Russia trying to topple Georgian government | publisher=CNN | date=11 August 2008 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/08/10/un.georgia/index.html}}</ref> Sergey Lavrov later claimed that Russian "peace enforcement" operation was not linked to the removal of Saakashvili from office. He said [[Condoleezza Rice]] "incorrectly interpreted" the phone conversation between them. He added if an agreement on non-use of military force is signed, "peace will be restored independently of the further fate of Saakashvili".<ref>{{cite news |script-title=ru:Чуркин пояснил слова Лаврова о том, что Саакашвили России не партнер: Какой приличный человек будет с ним разговаривать? |publisher=NEWSru.com |date=11 August 2008 |url=http://palm.newsru.com/russia/11aug2008/midspeech.html |language=ru}}</ref>
The [[Ministry of Defence (Russia)|Russian Defence Ministry]] announced that the [[Russian Navy]] sunk a Georgian missile boat after two alleged attacks of such boats earlier that day.<ref name="sunken_reported">{{cite news|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5hV2N6fVKS5slf10A13Dj_uIdaZ4QD92FJCEG0|title=Russian news agencies report sunken Georgian ship|publisher=Associated Press|date=10 August 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080813112941/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5hV2N6fVKS5slf10A13Dj_uIdaZ4QD92FJCEG0|archivedate=13 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=October 2012|bot=Legobot}}</ref> This was later confirmed by Russian Navy Assistant Commander Igor Dygalo (by 11 August). He said that four Georgian vessels were spotted sailing inside a "declared security zone" established by the Russian Navy off [[Abkhazia]]. The Russian fleet [[Battle off the coast of Abkhazia|retaliated with a barrage of artillery gunfire]]. One boat was sunk and the remaining three retreated in the direction of the Georgian port of [[Poti]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/08/10/destroy1/ |script-title=ru:Дыгало подтвердил уничтожение грузинского ракетного катера |publisher=Lenta.ru |date=11 August 2008|language=ru}}</ref>
40 Russian transport aircraft landed at Sukhumi airport and delivered military equipment.<ref name="1killed"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/08/11/abkhazia/ |script-title=ru:Россия ввела в Абхазию 9 тысяч военных и 350 бронемашин |publisher=Lenta.ru|date=11 August 2008|language=Russian}}</ref> In the evening of 10 August, more than 9,000 Russian troops and 350 armoured vehicles arrived at Sukhumi airport. Russian media later reported on 11 August that Russian Airborne Forces Commander Lieutenant General Valeriy Evtukhovich arrived in Abkhazia on 10 August.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/08/11/vdv/|script-title=ru:В Абхазию прибыл командующий ВДВ России|publisher=Lenta.ru|date=11 August 2008|language=Russian}}</ref>
According to Georgia, the total casualties due to the conflict were from 92 to 150.<ref name="smh_10aug"/> According to the BBC report, Georgian casualty figures were from 82 to about 130 killed, and this number included 37 civilians.<ref name="bbc pullout"/>
Around midnight, Russian and Georgian foreign ministers spoke over the phone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/08/10/direct/|script-title=ru:Министры иностранных дел России и Грузии начали переговоры|publisher=Lenta.ru |date=11 August 2008|language=ru}}</ref> The conversation ended with the Georgian minister promising to find out more about the situation in South Ossetia.<ref name="gorozia">{{cite web|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/08/10/talks1/|script-title=ru:Лавров призвал Грузию вывести войска из Южной Осетии|publisher=Lenta.ru|date=11 August 2008|language=ru}}</ref>
On 10 August, the Georgian governor of [[Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti]] Zaza Gorozia met with the commander of the peacekeeping forces in Abkhazia Sergey Chaban in Gali district of Abkhazia.<ref name="gorozia"/>
A Turkish TV crew was attacked on 10 August while heading into South Ossetia and taken to [[Vladikavkaz]] for interrogations. Several days later, they were released by Russian authorities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freemedia.at/home/singleview/article/ipi-condemns-detention-of-turkish-journalists-in-north-ossetia.html?L=0 |title=IPI Condemns Detention of Turkish Journalists in North Ossetia |publisher=International Press Institute}}</ref> [[Echo of Moscow]] reported that according to a journalist of Russian [[Newsweek]] magazine, South Ossetian separatists had killed two journalists.<ref name="expands_blitz"/>
=== August 11 === [[File:A Russian missile lies largely intact in a home in Gori.jpg|thumb|right|A Russian [[Booster (rocketry)|missile booster]] lies largely intact in a bedroom of a home in Gori.]]
The Georgian representative, Shota Utiashvili, said that Russian artillery began intensive shelling of Gori. He also said that Gori had endured air strikes prior to this and that Georgian troops were returning fire on the Russian positions. The Russian Ministry of Defense did not confirm or deny the reports.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/08/11/tanks/|script-title=ru:Российская артиллерия начала обстрел города Гори|publisher=Lenta.ru|date=11 August 2008|language=Russian}}</ref> Later, large numbers of Russian ground forces entered undisputed Georgian territory and were headed to [[Gori, Georgia|Gori]]. Western officials again reiterated their fears that Russia intended to overthrow the Georgian government. Anatoly Nogovitsyn had said on early 11 August that his country's aim was not to "break into" undisputed Georgia. Artillery shelling of the Georgian villages near South Ossetia had been witnessed by a reporter for ''The New York Times''. That day, even Abkhaz separatist government was concerned about possible Russian advance.<!--"Gori, a major staging area for the Georgian military"--><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/08/11/europe/11georgia.php |title=Russians push past separatist area to assault central Georgia |publisher=International Herald Tribune |date=11 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080815094808/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/08/11/europe/11georgia.php |archivedate=15 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref>
At 03:16 MSK, it was reported that Russians were not being allowed to leave Georgia.<ref name="hostage1">{{cite news|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/08/10/hostage/|script-title=ru:Российских граждан не выпускают из Грузии|publisher=Lenta.ru|date=11 August 2008|language=Russian}}</ref> In the morning such reports were denied by the Georgian Ministry of Internal Affairs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rian.ru/society/20080811/150257722.html|script-title=ru:МВД Грузии опровергает сообщения о задержании российских граждан|publisher=RIA Novosti|date=11 August 2008|language=Russian}}</ref> Later, the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs claimed that it had received such reports from over 360 stranded Russian citizens.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rian.ru/osetia_news/20080811/150275951.html|script-title=ru:Более 360 россиян сообщили о том, что их не выпускают из Грузии|publisher=RIA Novosti|date=11 August 2008|language=Russian}}</ref>
[[File:Ruins of a burnt apartment building in Gori.jpg|thumb|An apartment building in Gori, damaged during the war.]] After Georgian troops had left Tskhinvali on 10 August, the Russians indiscriminately bombed the civilian areas in Gori on 11 August by the afternoon and this was reported by ''The Guardian''. Aerodrome near the Azerbaijani border and a radar station in Tbilisi were also bombed by Russia on the same day.<!--The source claims that South Ossetia is 14 miles away from Gori.--><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/aug/11/georgia.russia11|title='I got my children out minutes before the bombs fell'|publisher=The Guardian|date=11 August 2008| first=Luke| last=Harding}}</ref> While the valley, where Gori is located, was held by Georgian forces until about {{convert|4|mi|km}} from Tskhinvali on 10 August, Western photographers said that by afternoon of 11 August the Georgians had fallen back about {{convert|6|mi|km}}. About a dozen bombs detonated on the northern rim of the valley at about 12:30 pm.<ref name="senaki_captured">{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/12/world/europe/12georgia.html |title=Russian Forces Capture Military Base in Georgia |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=11 August 2008}}</ref> That day, reporters witnessed a skirmish near Tskhinvali after the ceasefire was offered by Georgia and bombing of civilians in Tkviavi by Russia.<ref name="new_front_deeper"/><ref name="Several_fronts"/><ref name="ttime"/> Gori is located {{convert|17|mi|km|abbr=on}} from the South Ossetian boundary.<ref name="ttime"/>
Abkhaz defence minister [[Mirab Kishmaria]] threatened to kill all Georgian forces in the Kodori Gorge if they remained there. The Russian commander of the peacekeepers in Abkhazia, Major General Sergei Chaban, had given an ultimatum on 10 August to Georgian forces in the [[Zugdidi Municipality]] to disarm.<ref name="senaki_captured"/> Georgia declared it had received a Russian demand of disarming Georgian troops near Abkhazia through the U.N observers. In case of Georgian non-compliance, Russian troops would advance into undisputed Georgian territory.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gqI_T1AcjbA1Q67UBE01lvcAdQdQD92FVCOO0|title=Russians in Abkhazia issue ultimatum to Georgia|publisher=Associated Press|date=11 August 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080817011429/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gqI_T1AcjbA1Q67UBE01lvcAdQdQD92FVCOO0|archivedate=17 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=October 2012|bot=Legobot}}</ref>
South Ossetian government representative Irina Gagloeva [falsely] claimed in the morning that Georgia opened the irrigation canal, supposedly in an effort to flood the basements of Tskhinvali buildings with an intention to prevent civilians from hiding from bombings.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2008/08/11/flood/|script-title=ru:Грузию обвинили в попытке затопить Цхинвали|publisher=Lenta.ru|date=11 August 2008|language=Russian}}</ref>
Russian President Medvedev said that Russian troops had "completed a significant part of the operations to oblige Georgia, the Georgian authorities, to restore peace to South Ossetia."<ref name="senaki_captured"/>
Deputy Chief of the General Staff of Russia, Colonel General [[Anatoliy Nogovitsyn]], said the Georgian troops in South Ossetia were surrounded and surrendering. Nogovitsyn also said Russia was driving out all Georgian forces from Georgian villages, and that Russia was in full control of Georgian airspace. Nogovitsyn denied that Russa had bombed oil pipelines or civilian airport, but admitted bombing of a radar.<!--http://www.zagreb.mid.ru/cro/news/news2008-08-29.html http://dprogram.net/2008/08/11/russia-says-georgian-troops-in-sossetia-surrendering/--><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sindhtoday.net/world/11176.htm|title=Russia says Georgian troops surrendering in South Ossetia|publisher=Sindh Today|date=12 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080822164242/http://www.sindhtoday.net/world/11176.htm |archivedate=22 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref>
Bodyguards forced Georgian president Saakashvili to the ground in Gori when Russian planes flew over.<ref name="senaki_captured"/><ref name="ttime"/> Local civilians in Gori were warned that day by Georgian military of possible Russian advance; both civilians and military began abandoning Gori.<ref name="senaki_captured"/><ref name="new_front_deeper"/> Georgian official claimed that Gori was Although he claimed that Russians were not involved, Russian military traffic had been witnessed by an AP reporter. Abkhaz foreign minister, Sergei Shamba, said they had warned a U.N. observer mission in the gorge before the operation. Georgian president accused Abkhaz of ethnic cleansing.<!--http://www.gainesville.com/article/20080812/NEWS/971735973/-1/MAGAZINE&title=Russia_calls_halt_to_5_day_invasion_of_Georgia?p=2&tc=pg http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-51759669.html--><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/08/12/europe/EU-Georgia-Abkhazia.php|title=Abkhazia says Georgian troops pushed from province|publisher=International Herald Tribune|date=12 August 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080813170953/http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/08/12/europe/EU-Georgia-Abkhazia.php|archivedate=13 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> Russian General said that Abkhaz forces themselves expelled the Georgian troops from Abkhazia.<ref name="ap_russians_gori">{{cite news |url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gDNLWfQWKrQc48pITBUg9KT_6oVwD92H8MT80 |title=Georgian troops leave Abkhazia, Russians in Gori |agency=Associated Press |date=13 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080814165145/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gDNLWfQWKrQc48pITBUg9KT_6oVwD92H8MT80 |archivedate=14 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> Abkhaz fighters had accidentally killed one of their comrades during a military operation. The Abkhaz flag was flown over the former Georgian administrative building by midday. Only civilians found by the evening were two old women and four monks, since most civilians and Georgian military had fled. Abkhaz military said that a "mountain of weapons" was found. Herds of abandoned cattle were also found.<ref name="1killed">{{cite news|url=http://www.iwpr.net/?p=crs&s=f&o=346164&apc_state=henh|title=Abkhaz Open "Second Front"|author=Inal Khashig|publisher=Institute for War and Peace Reporting|date=14 August 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080814234013/http://www.iwpr.net/?p=crs&s=f&o=346164&apc_state=henh|archivedate=14 August 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Georgian refugees from the Kodori gorge said that they fled the shelling, which had damaged many houses.<ref name="offensive_before_medvedev"/>
Georgian President Mikheil Saakashvili said that Georgia would declare Russian peacekeepers as occupiers and the breakaway territories of Abkhazia and South Ossetia as occupied territory.<ref name="offensive_before_medvedev"/> Saakashvili announced at a large rally outside parliament that Georgia would leave the [[Commonwealth of Independent States]].<!--http://www.euronews.com/2008/08/12/saakashvili-leads-georgian-show-of-unity/ http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/1,7340,L-3581545,00.html--><ref name="sky_smokescreen"/> Georgia filed a lawsuit with the [[International Court of Justice]], accusing Russia of carrying out ethnic cleansing between 1993 and 2008.<ref>{{cite news|title=Georgia begins legal move|url=http://www.teletext.co.uk/news/national/7d45e0aa0f7edcc5457a450517ccf53a/Georgia+begins+legal+move.aspx|publisher=[[Teletext Ltd.]]|date=12 August 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821023720/http://www.teletext.co.uk/news/national/7d45e0aa0f7edcc5457a450517ccf53a/Georgia+begins+legal+move.aspx|archivedate=21 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=October 2015}}</ref>
Associated Press reported that there was still sporadic fighting and artillery exchanges in Tskhinvali on 12 August. Georgian villages in South Ossetia were reportedly burned. BP announced that day it had shut down Baku-Supsa pipeline.<ref name="offensive_before_medvedev"/> The plane carrying the United Nations humanitarian aid arrived in Georgia that day.<ref name="violating_truce"/>
French President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] mediated a ceasefire plan between Russia and Georgia, which included provision to withdraw all troops to the lines they held before the war broke out. Russian president Medvedev had made 13 August a day of national mourning in Russia.<ref name="news2">{{cite news|title=Georgia and Russia agree on truce|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7557457.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=13 August 2008}}</ref> After meeting Medvedev, French president Sarkozy told the news conference in Moscow that although a ceasefire had been agreed upon, a peace agreement was not yet reached by Russia and Georgia. Georgian Prime Minister Lado Gurgenidze said that although Georgian president Saakashvili had signed the four-point plan, Georgia would remain "prepared for everything" until Russia actually suspended hostilities.<ref name="hurriyet"/>
=== August 13 === By 2 am, Medvedev and Saakashvili had agreed on a peace plan.<ref name="accord_withdrawal"/> Russian troops would have to withdraw to their "normal bases of encampment" meanwhile being able to "implement additional security measures." This agreement caused an American official to state later that such unclear meaning "would allow the Russians to do almost anything."<ref name="bush_sending_aid"/> French President Nicolas Sarkozy said at a press conference in Tbilisi that both Georgia and Russia accepted the peace plan.<ref name="sky_smokescreen"/>
Parts of [[Gori, Georgia|Gori]], a strategic central Georgian city, was occupied by a Russian tank battalion several hours after the ceasefire agreement. Talks of a possible Russian advance on Tbilisi began.<ref name="bush_sending_aid"/> The head of [[National Security Council of Georgia]] said that 50 Russian tanks had entered Gori.<ref name="ap_russians_gori"/>
Abkhaz ''de facto'' president Sergei Bagapsh arrived in the Kodori gorge by helicopter on the morning. He declared that the Abkhaz authorities had retaken last Abkhaz territory controlled by Georgia.<ref name="1killed"/> Despite earlier Russian claims that the separatists themselves had expelled Georgian troops from the gorge, Anatoly Nogovitsyn said on 13 August that Georgian troops had been disarmed by Russian peacekeepers. Anatoly Nogovitsyn claimed that there still were sporadic clashes in South Ossetia.<ref name="violating_truce"/>
Foreign Minister [[Sergey Lavrov]] said that Russian forces in Georgia continued their presence to support peacekeepers and Georgian troops had abandoned "a major arsenal of armaments and military equipment" that needed to be guarded. Russians would provide the residents of Gori with food, he said. General Vyacheslav Nikolayevich of the Pskov Airborne Division had claimed Russian troops would remain on the outskirts of Gori instead of entering the city.<ref name="bush_sending_aid"/>
A reporter for ''The Guardian'' said that "the idea there is a ceasefire is ridiculous", and that Chechen, Cossack and Ossetian irregulars were following advancing Russian military and burning Georgian villages near [[Gori, Georgia|Gori]]. Anatoliy Nogovitsyn had claimed that Russians entered Gori only to negotiate with the local authorities, who were found to be absent, but there were no Russian tanks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/aug/13/georgia.russia6|title=Georgian villages burned and looted as Russian tanks advance|author=Luke Harding|publisher=The Guardian|date=13 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rian.ru/osetia_news/20080813/150342553.html |script-title=ru:Миротворцы опровергли утверждения об атаках на Гори |publisher=RIA Novosti |date=13 August 2008|language=Russian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rian.ru/osetia_mm/20080812/150322734.html |script-title=ru:Российская армия не атаковала Гори - Генштаб ВС РФ |publisher=RIA Novosti |date=12 August 2008|language=Russian}}</ref> Sky News correspondents confirmed that Russian tanks were in Gori. Sky News correspondents said that they were robbed at gunpoint, apparently by South Ossetian irregulars, and they had to return to Gori on foot. Norwegian journalists were also robbed in the centre of Gori that day.<ref name="violate">{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/625923/russia-troops-violate-ceasefire |title=Russia Troops Violate Ceasefire |date=13 August 2008 |publisher=Sky News}}</ref> ''The New York Times'' reported Czech journalists were robbed and that "almost completely empty" Gori was "firmly occupied". That day, ''The New York Times'' interviewed Russian commanders, who did not view their presence in Gori, the city where [[Joseph Stalin]] was born, as a violation of the ceasefire. One Russian soldier even said, "If [Saakashvili] does not understand the situation, we’ll have to go farther. It’s just 60 kilometers to Tbilisi." Another Russian officer confirmed attacks on Georgian villages.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/14/world/europe/14gori.html |title=Russian Soldiers Occupying Stalin’s Birth City Are Buoyed by Battle With Georgia |publisher=The New York Times |date=13 August 2008}}</ref> Human Rights Watch researchers reported that militias were responsible for "terrifying scenes of destruction" in ethnic Georgian villages. Anna Neistat said that Russian claims of systematic atrocities by Georgian military could not be supported by any evidence.<ref name="bush_sending_aid"/>
An Associated Press reporter witnessed the Russian tanks and military vehicles leaving Gori for Tbilisi, however the Russians stopped about a hour's drive from Tbilisi and encamped.<ref name="violating_truce">{{cite news |title=Russian convoy heads into Georgia, violating truce |url=http://www.unian.info/world/137400-russian-convoy-heads-into-georgia-violating-truce.html |publisher=UNIAN |date=13 August 2008}}</ref> Georgian troops occupied the road {{convert|6|mi|km}} closer to Tbilisi and began preparing a defense line. South Ossetian militias reportedly had begun looting in Gori.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/G/GEORGIA_ROAD_TO_TBILISI?SITE=ALANN&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |title=Russian feint toward Tbilisi shows truce fragile |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=13 August 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820085728/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/G/GEORGIA_ROAD_TO_TBILISI?SITE=ALANN&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |archivedate=20 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref>
Ukrainian President [[Viktor Yushchenko]] signed a decree requiring that Russian Black Sea Fleet should seek the permission of Ukrainian authorities at least 72 hours prior to any movements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unian.net/eng/news/news-267018.html |title=Yushchenko "locks" Russian ships in Crimea |publisher=UNIAN |date=13 August 2008}}</ref>
American president [[George W. Bush]] sent American troops on a humanitarian mission. This was hailed by Georgian president Saakashvili, which labelled the relief operation as a "turning point". Saakashvili assessed the American operation as a defence of Georgian ports and airports, however American officials denied this, with one senior official saying, "We won’t be protecting the airport or seaport, but we’ll certainly protect our assets if we need to." The first American [[C-17 Globemaster III|C-17 Globemaster]] aircraft arrived in Tbilisi that day and brought humanitarian and medical supplies. [[Condoleezza Rice]] and George Bush accused Russia of continued presence in Georgia in violation of the ceasefire, however Russia claimed its actions complied with the ceasefire.<ref name="bush_sending_aid">{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/14/world/europe/14georgia.html |title=Bush, Sending Aid, Demands That Moscow Withdraw |publisher=The New York Times |date=13 August 2008}}</ref> After Bush had announced his support for Georgia, Georgian officials said that Russian began withdrawal from Gori. Russian official estimated that Gori would be returned to Georgians in two days.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jxWSXsJwitQHhYrvd-DUbRfgQdEA |title=Russians begin pulling back from flashpoint Georgian city |publisher=AFP |date=12 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520165917/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jxWSXsJwitQHhYrvd-DUbRfgQdEA |archivedate=20 May 2011}}</ref> Saakashvili said, "We have been warning them a large scale Russian invasion is coming. (The) State Department told us the Russians are not going to do that." Saakashvili denied Russia's claim that Georgia provoked the war and noted he had to cancel his trip to the Olympics because Georgia had either to "respond or to surrender."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,402982,00.html |title=Bush Orders Military to Deliver Aid to Georgia |date=13 August 2008 |publisher=Fox News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080813223752/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,402982,00.html |archivedate=13 August 2008}}</ref>
Although journalists had reported that Russian military violated the ceasefire, Anatoly Nogovitsyn claimed on 13 August that it was Georgia in violation of ceasefire. According to Al Jazeera, "Russia's military on Wednesday repeatedly denied that any troops were inside Gori." Georgian president Saakashvili had accused Russia of "Balkan-type and World War II-type ethnic cleansing and purification campaigns".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2008/08/2008813153517926662.html|title=Russian forces sink Georgian ships|publisher=Al Jazeera English|date=14 August 2008}}</ref> Russia said that "despite the assurances from the Georgian side that they have ended all military activities, Russian troops shot down a second Georgian drone over Tskhinvali earlier today."<ref name="violate"/> Georgia reported that 175 Georgians had died from the war.<ref name="violating_truce"/>
[[File:Tbilisi-2008-08-14.jpg|thumb|250px|Georgian soldiers returning to Tbilisi from the front outside Gori on August 14, 2008.]]
=== August 14 === 14 August had been announced as a day of mourning for the South Ossetian victims in Abkhazia.<ref name="1killed"/>
It was reported on early 14 August that there was calm in Gori.<ref name="bbc_handover">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7560100.stm|title=Russians begin Georgia handover|publisher=BBC News|date=14 August 2008}}</ref> At about 10:00, joint patrols of Georgian police and Russian forces in Gori was ordered by Russian major general while Russian troops were preparing to withdraw.<ref name="vows_retort">{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/15/world/europe/15georgia.html |title=Russia Vows to Support Two Enclaves, in Retort to Bush |publisher=The New York Times |date=14 August 2008}}</ref> ''Interfax'' reported at 12:10 MSK that the Russian army gave back control of Gori to the Georgian Police. The representative of the Russian Ministry of Defence, major-general [[Vyacheslav Borisov]] claimed that the rumours about damaged town and marauding did not correspond to reality. Secretary of National Defence Сouncil of Georgia Alexander Lomaia, who was in Gori negotiating with the Russians, said on "Rustavi-2" TV on the live broadcast that the situation in Gori was calm and Russian army only did patrolling job.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://interfax.ru/politics/txt.asp?id=27186 |script-title=ru:Покидая Гори |date=14 August 2008 |publisher=Interfax |language=Russian |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080814174250/http://www.interfax.ru/politics/txt.asp?id=27186 |archivedate=14 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=October 2015}}</ref>
At about 13:00, joint patrol efforts in Gori broke down due to apparent tensions among personnel.<ref name="vows_retort"/> Although the Russian troops were ready for the handover of Gori, they postponed it. It was alleged that this happened due to Moscow assessing the U.S. humanitarian mission, which meant support for President Saakashvili. A stand-off took place near Gori between the Georgian police and the Russian forces with the Russian tanks arriving as reinforcements and the Georgians left the area.<ref name="Russia destroying">{{cite web |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/georgia/2558812/Russia-destroying-military-bases-in-Georgia.html |title=Russia destroying military bases in Georgia |publisher=The Telegraph |date=14 August 2008}}</ref> It was reported that near Gori five explosions took place. Russians reportedly had probably blown up a military depot near Gori.<ref name="vows_retort"/><ref name="Russia destroying"/><ref name="gates_rice"/> A BBC correspondent in Gori reported that day to have heard explosions.<ref name="bbc_handover"/> Georgian police allegedly reported that the refusal of the South Ossetians to leave Gori caused the Russian withdrawal to be canceled.<ref name="gates_rice"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gTixpvigH9KqyxiYCosiqaIn1OQAD92I76M01 |title=Russian tanks deter Georgian entry to Gori |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=14 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819215451/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gTixpvigH9KqyxiYCosiqaIn1OQAD92I76M01 |archivedate=19 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> Georgian official Alexander Lomaia was negotiating permission for the Georgian police to enter Gori. ''The Telegraph'' reported that "Meanwhile, South Ossetian irregulars continuing to loot and pillage in Gori and nearby Georgian villages, often with the encouragement of Russian troops".<ref name="Russia destroying"/> Anatoly Nogovitsyn claimed that day that Russia was not prepared for withdrawal from Gori, since Russian forces had to protect an abandoned ammunition.<ref name="bbc_handover"/>
Witnesses in [[Poti]] reported that Russian tanks had entered the town and were looting or destroying infrastructure. Russia denied that its troops were in Poti.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/asiaCrisis/idUSLE126209 |title=Russian tanks in Georgia's Poti - witnesses |publisher=Reuters |date=14 August 2008}}</ref> Anatoly Nogovitsyn later said that Russians were gathering intelligence in Poti. It was reported that some of the troops occupying Zugdidi wore blue peacekeeping helmets while others wore green camouflage helmets.<ref name="gates_rice"/>
President Medvedev met with South Ossetian and Abkhaz leaders in Moscow on 14 August. Georgian parliament decided to withdraw Georgia from the CIS.<ref name="bbc_handover"/> [[Human Rights Watch]] had only confirmed the death of 44 South Ossetian civilians and accused Russia of reporting false casualty figures. Two flights delivered the U.S. humanitarian aid on a C-17 military plane to Georgia.<ref name="Russia destroying"/>
U.S. Secretary of State Rice said that day "the provisional ceasefire that was agreed to really must go into place. And that means that military activities have to cease". Although Defence Secretary Gates accused the Russians of going "far beyond reasserting the autonomy of Abkhazia and South Ossetia," Gates nonetheless said that there was "no prospect" of US troops being deployed.<ref name="gates_rice">{{cite web |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/aug/14/georgia.russia7 |title=Georgia conflict could set back Russia's US relations 'for years' |publisher=The Guardian |date=14 August 2008}}</ref>
=== August 15 ===
[[Agence France-Presse]] reported that amid the ruins and tanks in the South Ossetian capital, the remaining residents shared insufficient goods and wondered why humanitarian aid promised by Russia had not arrived.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/news/world/south-ossetians-wait-for-aid-in-bombedout-capital/2008/08/15/1218307168921.html|title=South Ossetians wait for aid in bombed-out capital|publisher=Brisbane Times |date=15 August 2008}}</ref>
[[Reuters]] reported that Russian forces had pushed to {{convert|34|mi|km}} from Tbilisi, the closest during the war, and stopped in Igoeti at the same time as [[United States Secretary of State]] [[Condoleezza Rice]] was in Tbilisi meeting President Saakashvili. According to the report, 17 APCs and 200 soldiers marched towards Igoeti. The convoy included a military ambulance, snipers, rocket-propelled grenades and initially, three helicopters.<ref name="34_miles">{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/wtMostRead/idUSLF7284720080815 |title=Russian convoy moves deeper inside Georgia: witness |publisher=Reuters |date=15 August 2008 |first=James |last=Kilner}}</ref> The Georgian troops and police were nearby where the Russians had stopped, but did not resist them. According to the [[International New York Times|International Herald Tribune]] (IHT), the move "opened a new security vacuum between Gori and [Igoeti], creating fresh targets" for "looters and armed gangs in uniform - many of them apparently Ossetians, Chechens and Cossacks - [who] have operated behind the army's path, ransacking villages largely vacated by fleeing civilians."<ref name="iht_16Aug"/>
After about five-hour meeting with Condoleezza Rice, President Saakashvili signed an EU-brokered ceasefire.<ref name="BBC_Rice"/> Rice in Tbilisi declared: "Russian forces need to leave Georgia at once. This is no longer 1968." Saakashvili described Russians as "21st century barbarians". He blamed the West for provoking the conflict by not properly reacting to Russia's previous military acts and not allowing Georgia to become a NATO member as soon as possible. The Russian General Staff said at its daily news briefing on the same day that no shooting occurred in the previous 24 hours. Russian ground troops were mostly based around Gori.<ref name="justification">{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSL768040420080815 |title=Bush criticizes Moscow's actions in Georgia |publisher=Reuters |date=15 August 2008 |author1=David Alexander |author2=Oleg Shchedrov |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828054952/http://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSL768040420080815?sp=true |archivedate=28 August 2008}}</ref>
German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] met Russian president Dmitry Medvedev in [[Sochi]]. Medvedev said in Sochi that he couldn't see the people of South Ossetia and Abkhazia wishing to be sill a part of Georgia and claimed not Russia, but local residents opposed international peacekeeping forces in the two regions.<ref name="BBC_Rice">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7577150.stm |title=Day-by-day: Georgia-Russia crisis | date=22 August 2008 | publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
Amidst what the Associated Press described as "intense diplomacy" to pressure Russia to withdraw from Georgia, Interfax News Agency quoted Russian General Anatoly Nogovitsyn as saying that Poland "is exposing itself to a strike" by welcoming an American missile battery. Associated Press reported that Gori "is key to when – or if – Russia will honour the terms of a ceasefire". Despite earlier reports of Russian troops moving towards [[Kutaisi]], Georgian official denied the Russian presence in Kutaisi.<ref name="theglobeandmail">{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080815.wgeorgia0815/BNStory/International/home |title=Diplomatic whirlwind begins as West presses Russia to pull out |date=15 August 2008|publisher=The Globe and Mail |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080818002301/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080815.wgeorgia0815/BNStory/International/home |archivedate=18 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref>
Human Rights Watch stated they had documented the use of cluster bombs against Georgian civilians by Russian Air Force and urged Russia not to use such banned weapons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.humanrightswatch.org/english/docs/2008/08/14/georgi19625.htm |title=Georgia: Russian Cluster Bombs Kill Civilians |date=15 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080823015804/http://www.humanrightswatch.org/english/docs/2008/08/14/georgi19625.htm |archivedate=23 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> The accusation was dismissed by the Russian Defence Ministry and one Russian official claimed that the HRW used "biased witnesses" as source of information.<ref name="theglobeandmail"/>
=== August 16 ===
The BBC reported that the Russian army entered the port of Poti on 16 August "at least the third time" since the war began.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7562959.stm |title=Russia in control and on the move |publisher=BBC News |date=16 August 2008 |first=Richard |last=Galpin}}</ref> The Russian forces that were occupying Poti, as well as military bases in Gori and Senaki, that day destroyed the military bases which were based on the NATO standard and the American-made or supplied arsenal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/aug/16/georgia.russia1 |title=Six days that broke one country - and reshaped the world order |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=16 August 2008 |first=Ian |last=Traynor}}</ref>
Early on 16 August, [[Defensive fighting position|foxholes]] were dug up by the Russians in Igoeti. In the afternoon, the Russian forces withdrew from their positions in Igoeti.<ref name="defying"/> The Russian withdrawal from Igoeti was reported by the western news agencies. The IHT noted that Russian soldiers still were in Zugdidi and Senaki in western Georgia, and that Russian armored patrol was on the road to Abasha near Kutaisi. In Poti, 16 coastal guard vessels were confiscated by the Russian military.<ref name="iht_16Aug">{{cite web|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/08/16/europe/16military.php |title=Russians consolidate positions in Georgia |publisher=International Herald Tribune |date=16 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819160916/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/08/16/europe/16military.php |archivedate=19 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> The major Georgian east-west highway was controlled by the Russian forces by occupying the positions around Gori and the city of Senaki.<ref name="defying"/>
The Georgian Foreign Ministry announced that Russian troops destroyed a major railway bridge in the [[Kaspi district, Georgia|Kaspi district]] responsible for bisecting Georgia from east to west and linking the hinterland to seaports on the Black Sea. Russians denied blowing up the bridge. However, the destruction of the bridge caused Azerbaijan to halt oil shipments and Armenian supply of goods was also interrupted.<!--"Let them take Saakashvili with them," griped Giorgi Aptsiauri, another white-haired farmer, referring to the Georgian president. "Look what condition we're in! If he steps down, the Russians will stop everything."--><ref>{{cite news |first=Megan K. |last=Stack |title=Key Georgia rail bridge is destroyed |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-ossetia17-2008aug17,0,5302823.story |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date=17 August 2008}}</ref>
Dmitry Medvedev told the permanent members of the Security Council that he had signed the ceasefire document on 12 August in Moscow.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kremlin.ru/eng/text/news/2008/08/205406.shtml |title=President Medvedev signed a plan to resolve the Georgian-South Ossetia conflict, based on the six principles previously agreed on. |publisher=The Kremlin |date=16 August 2008 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5jCyBkt5f |archivedate=22 August 2009}}{{dead link|date=October 2015}}</ref>
''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that South Ossetian forces had occupied undefended [[Akhalgori]] on 16 August and that one South Ossetian fighter said,"It will be part of an independent country within the Russian Federation." It was reported that new checkpoints were set up by the Russian forces on the Tbilisi-Gori road and that a Grad multiple-rocket launcher was moving towards Tbilisi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/aug/18/georgia.russia1|title=Tanks and Katyushas bristle round isolated Tbilisi|author=Luke Harding|publisher=The Guardian|date=18 August 2008}}</ref>
Georgian Foreign Ministry stated that Russian forces and Abkhaz separatists had taken 13 villages and the [[Inguri Dam|Inguri hydropowerpower plant]]. After this action, the border of Abkhazia was shifted toward the [[Inguri River]].<ref name="defying">{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080816.wgeorgiaupdate0816/BNStory/International/home |title=Russia defying Georgian truce, U.S. says |publisher=Associated Press |date=16 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819223036/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080816.wgeorgiaupdate0816/BNStory/International/home |archivedate=19 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref>
=== August 17 ===
Richard Galpin of the BBC, who had spent the past two days travelling from Poti to Tbilisi, reported that Georgian forces "seemed to be surrendering control of the highway to the Russians".<ref name="pledge"/> According to [[BBC]]'s Gabriel Gatehouse, there was a "much-reduced" Russian military presence in Gori that day and humanitarian aid was being delivered, however Russians still controlled major entry and exit points of Gori. The Russian commander claimed that his troops remained in Gori to avoid looting and would only leave after the Georgian police was ready. Major General Vyacheslav Borisov claimed that day to have ordered Russian peacekeepers to replace Russian soldiers in Igoeti, but this was disputed by Georgia.<ref name="pledge">{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7566199.stm |title=Russia pledge on Georgia pull-out |publisher=BBC News |date=17 August 2008}}</ref> ''[[The Times]]'' reported that Russia was occupying about a third of Georgia and that Ossetian militiamen were wearing white armbands to ease their recognition for Russians.<ref name="Sunday_Times_17_Aug_09"/>
Russian president Medvedev promised Sarkozy that Russian troops would begin withdrawal to South Ossetia on 18 August. Georgian president Saakashvili said that "Georgia will never give up a square kilometer of its territory." Earlier, the residents of Zugdidi had protested against the Russian occupation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20080817/ap_on_re_eu/georgia_russia |title=Russia: Will begin pullout from Georgia on Monday |publisher=Associated Press |date=17 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820012522/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20080817/ap_on_re_eu/georgia_russia |archivedate=20 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref>
''The New York Times'' reported that Russia had deployed [[OTR-21 Tochka|SS-21 Scarab]] missile launchers to South Ossetia on 15 August.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/18/world/europe/18georgia.html?hp |title=Pledging to Leave Georgia, Russia Tightens Its Grip |publisher=The New York Times |date=17 August 2008}}</ref>
=== August 18 === Anatoly Nogovitsyn from the Russian General Staff said around noon that Russia had started to pull troops from Georgia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,572751,00.html |title=Russischer Generalstab meldet Truppenabzug |publisher=Der Spiegel |date=18 August 2008 |language=German}}</ref>
[[RIA Novosti]] reported that Russian military equipment was being pulled out of the South Ossetian capital Tskinvali.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20080818/116103462.html |title=Russian troops start pullout from South Ossetia capital |publisher=RIA Novosti |date=18 August 2008}}</ref>
Four Russian armored vehicles in the village of Igoeti appeared to be moving to the village of Lamiskana, however they were resisted by Georgian police, which had made a barrier with their vehicles. The Russian general ordered his soldiers to drive over the police cars, however the Georgian policemen managed to get out of the cars before the Russians drove over their cars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ireport.com/docs/DOC-62034|title=Russian tanks drive over Georgian police vehicles|publisher=CNN iReport|date=18 August 2008}}</ref>
Late on afternoon, Russian military units were still holding the center of Georgia and Russian military convoys were moving in and out of Gori. In western Georgia, there was no signs of a Russian withdrawal from Zugdidi by mid-afternoon, but a convoy of 12 Russian military vehicles had rolled south toward the port of Poti in the morning. Russian troops were still occupying an air base and other positions in Senaki.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/117/story/49042.html |title=No sign that Russians have begun to leave Georgia |publisher=McClatchy DC |date=18 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520083854/http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2008/08/18/49042/no-sign-that-russians-have-begun.html |archivedate=20 May 2011}}{{dead link|date=October 2015}}</ref>
Russian Foreign ministry stated that according to 1999 document of the Joint Control Commission, peacekeepers were permitted to operate a "security corridor" extending about {{convert|5|mi|km|abbr=on}} in each direction from South Ossetian boundary, thus including parts of the main Georgian east-west highway. However, Russian forces actually had never crossed into Georgia proper before the war.<ref name="senaki"/>
=== August 19 ===
''The Wall Street Journal'' said Russian forces had seized control of [[Poti]] on the morning, which is the economically significant port. Georgian soldiers in Poti were captured by the Russian forces and taken to the base in Senaki four hours later. The Russians also captured five American jeeps.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB121913118324652571.html |title=Russia Briefly Seizes Georgian Port |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |date=19 August 2008}}</ref> Later, American [[Humvee]]s moved down the road to Abkhazia. A top Russian military official claimed that armed Georgian soldiers in Poti were driving the Humvees and were detained at a checkpoint, however the Georgians said that 21 Georgian soldiers were guarding the port from looting, and that American Humvees used in a joint exercise were packed in a container to be shipped back to the United States.<ref name="senaki"/> An Azerbaijani news source quoted a Poti port official as saying, "All workers were expelled from the port [yesterday at night]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.trend.az/capital/energy/1273609.html |title=Activity of Georgian Black Sea Port of Poti Paralyzed |publisher=Trend |date=19 August 2008}}</ref>
Prisoners of war were exchanged by Russia and Georgia. A Georgian official said that although his country exchanged five Russian servicemen for fifteen Georgians (including two civilians), Georgia suspected that Russia still held two more Georgians.<ref name="pows">{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-Georgia/idUSLJ34288420080819|title=Russian, Georgian forces exchange prisoners |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=19 August 2008 |author1=Margarita Antidze |author2=Matt Robinson}}</ref> The exchange took place in Igoeti and two of the exchanged Russians were pilots. Earlier, Russia had claimed that Russian troops were pulling back while Georgia was not complying with the ceasefire.<ref name="nato-igoeti"/>
NATO countries convened for an emergency summit in [[Brussels]] to find some consensuses on a response towards Russia in regard to the conflict in Georgia.<ref name="nato-igoeti">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7569357.stm|title=Nato holds Georgia crisis talks|publisher=BBC News|date=19 August 2008}}</ref> Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov levelled accusations at NATO of being "unobjective and biased" in maintaining support for a "criminal regime" that was "failing." Russian president Medvedev had told French president Sarkozy that the withdrawal would be complete by 21–22 August, however 500 Russian soldiers would guard South Ossetian border.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7571104.stm |title=Russia Hits Back at Nato warning |publisher=BBC News |date=19 August 2008}}</ref>
''The New York Times'' reported that Russian troops were patrolling villages in western Georgia with tanks and armored personnel carriers daily. Russians had deployed artillery along major roads between Poti and Abkhazia. Reinforced trenches for a Russian checkpoint north of Gori was being built by engineering platoon and Russian armored vehicles were overlooking Gori and Igoeti from high ground. Most of the conflict zone was reportedly in need of water and food. Georgian villagers were hiding in fear of looters.<ref name="senaki">{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/20/world/europe/20georgia.html | publisher=The New York Times | first1=Michael | last1=Schwirtz | first2=Ellen | last2=Barry | title=Russia Sends Mixed Signs on Pullout From Georgia | date=19 August 2008}}</ref>
Interfax reported that the head of Russian Federal Security Service said that according to intelligence reports, Georgia planned terrorist attacks in southern Russia, and security was increased at transportation hubs, industrial plants and densely populated areas.<ref name="senaki"/> Martin Nesirky, a spokesman for the OSCE, said that OSCE would deploy 20 international monitors in addition to 8 already present in South Ossetia, who would begin arriving on 21 August and be let in the area adjacent to South Ossetia.<ref name="senaki"/>
=== August 20 ===
The [[United Nations Security Council]] met at 16:15 [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] on 19 August to hear briefings about the situation, including brief statements of [[Lynn Pascoe]] about human rights abuses and relief shipments to the conflict area, and the promise of a permanent Russian military base in South Ossetia. The Georgian ambassador reported cases of destruction of their civilian and military infrastructure and reported a [[cyber attack]] from Russia. The Russian ambassador accused other parties of engaging in "propaganda".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.undemocracy.com/securitycouncil/meeting_5961 |title=Security Council meeting 5961 |date=19 August 2008 |publisher=UNdemocracy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080823172709/http://www.undemocracy.com/securitycouncil/meeting_5961 |archivedate=23 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref>
On 20 August, a French-drafted UN Security Council resolution was not passed because of Russian resistance and Vitaly Churkin said, "It's a waste of time because the process of the withdrawal of Russian forces will continue." A claim was made by an official from the Poti port that the Russian military had withdrawn after blowing up a vessel and capturing military equipment.<ref name="BBC_20_08_2008">{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7571506.stm |title=Russia rejects UN Georgia Draft |publisher=BBC News |date=20 August 2008}}</ref>
Russia reduced initial civilian casualty figures of 1,600 people for the conflict to 133 ethnic Ossetian civilians listed as dead. Russia also reduced the number of its killed military to 64, but increased the number of its wounded military to more than 300. Georgia said that 160 Georgian soldiers were killed and 300 were missing. International Criminal Court stated that it was analysing the conflict.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7572635.stm |title=Russia scales down Georgia toll |publisher=BBC News |date=20 August 2008}}</ref>
=== August 21 ===
Russia's emergencies ministry declared in a statement, "A total of 17,912 people returned in the period August 12–20."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20080821/116184724.html |title=Russia says some 18,000 refugees return to S. Ossetia |publisher=RIA Novosti |date=21 August 2008}}</ref>
Russian forces still continued to occupy Gori and Igoeti. Russian Defense Minister Anatoly Serdyukov repeated Medvedev's claim that Russian troops would withdraw to South Ossetia by the end of 22 August. Commander of Russian land forces, General Vladimir Boldyrev, claimed that withdrawal of troops not manning the security zones to Russia would last for 10 days. Near Poti, an AP photographer and TV crew were detained by the Russian soldiers and their equipment was confiscated. The residents of Poti protested against the Russian occupation. Associated Press reported that "tanks, armored personnel carriers and trucks were seen moving in both directions on the road from Gori to Tskhinvali." There were reports of Georgian villages being looted and burned. Conductor [[Valery Gergiev]] held the concert during the night in front of the South Ossetian parliament in Tskhinvali.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20080821/ap_on_re_eu/georgia_russia |title=Russians dig in but still promise Georgia pullout |date=21 August 2008 |publisher=Associated Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080825004203/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20080821/ap_on_re_eu/georgia_russia |archivedate=25 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref>
American President George Bush told Georgian President Saakashvili during their phone conversation that the United States sought to end the Russian "siege" of Georgia.<ref name="bush_igoeti"/>
=== August 22 ===
Russian forces withdrew from Igoeti, and Georgian police advanced towards Gori. Colonel-general Nogovitsyn demonstrated to reporters the map of the "zone of responsibility" that would be established in Georgia after the military withdrawal. Novogitsyn commented on the Russian military presence on parts of the highway around Gori by saying that "if needed we reserve the right to boost these forces with units from the Russian peacekeepers’ contingent".<ref name="bush_igoeti">{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article4589586.ece | publisher=The Times | first=Tony | last=Halpin | title=Russian troops in partial pullout keeping checkpoints within Georgia | date=23 August 2008 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827213127/www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article4589586.ece |archivedate=27 Aug 2008}}</ref>
Russia had withdrawn most troops from Georgia by the evening to Abkhazia and South Ossetia and Georgia's main east-west highway was effectively reopened. ''The New York Times'' reported: "The Russian incursion into Georgia had already energized the world’s corps of military attachés, who have been provided a rare chance to see the Russian Army operating in the field. [...] And many Russian troops, after several years of emphasis by former President Vladimir V. Putin on developing units of volunteers and not conscripts, looked fit and alert."<ref name="23georgia">{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/23/world/europe/23georgia.html |title=Russia Pulls the Bulk of Its Forces Out of Georgia |author=C.J. Chivers |publisher=The New York Times |date=22 August 2008}}</ref>
Russia claimed that its promised troop pullout from Georgia was complete and announced that Russia would permanently maintain a large buffer zone near South Ossetia and Abkhazia. According to a White House spokesman, American President Bush and French President Sarkozy had agreed that Russia was not in compliance with the ceasefire.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.net/en/article/22/08/2008/us-disputes-russia-s-claims-of-georgia-withdrawal/ |title=US disputes Russia’s claims of Georgia withdrawal |publisher=euronews |date=22 August 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080823055245/http://www.euronews.net/en/article/22/08/2008/us-disputes-russia-s-claims-of-georgia-withdrawal/ |archivedate=23 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> The Kremlin, however, said in a formal announcement on 23 August, that President Sarkozy, in a telephone conversation with Russian President [[Dmitry Medvedev|Medvedev]], had shown satisfaction with the Russian withdrawal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.focus-fen.net/index.php?id=n150284 |title=Sarkozy satisfied with implementation of Russian troops withdrawal from Georgia plan |date=23 August 2008 |publisher=FOCUS Information Agency |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916233813/http://www.focus-fen.net/index.php?id=n150284 |archivedate=16 September 2008}}{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref>
=== August 23 === Units of the Georgian Army returned to Gori. Russian military was pulling out from Zugdidi to Abkhazia. Russian troops left the military base in Senaki after looting it for more than a week. However, Russian checkpoints remained near Gori as well as in so-called buffer zones near the borders with Abkhazia and South Ossetia, and two Russian observer posts remained near Poti.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/24/world/europe/24georgia.html | publisher=The New York Times | first=Michael | last=Schwirtz | title=Georgia Prepares for Refugees; Russians Declare Pullback Finished | date=24 August 2008}}</ref> At a news conference General Anatoly Nogovitsyn insisted, "These patrols were envisaged in the international agreement. Poti is outside of the security zone, but that does not mean we will sit behind a fence watching them riding around in Hummers." Nogovitsyn claimed that Georgia was rearming for "another act of aggression". He claimed that "2,100 people" were killed in the conflict.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=RIA Novosti |url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20080823/116235138.html |title=Russian troops to patrol Georgian port of Poti - Gen.Staff |date=23 August 2008}}</ref>
=== August 24 ===
With Russian forces still within the port of Poti, a US warship arrived with aid supplies in [[Batumi]] and two more warships were expected to arrive. The supplies delivered by the destroyer USS McFaul would be unloaded by a floating crane since the warship did not fit into the port. The BBC reported that "apart from delivering aid, the arrival of US naval personnel is undoubtedly intended to send a signal to the Russians - that America is serious about its support for Georgia." Georgia stated that day that a fuel train exploded near Gori.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7579506.stm |title=US Warship reaches Georgian port |publisher=BBC News |date=24 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/us-warship-docks-in-black-sea-port-with-georgia-aid-907401.html |title=US warship docks in Black Sea port with Georgia aid |publisher=The Independent |date=23 October 2011}}</ref>
=== August 25 ===
The Deputy Defense Minister of Abkhazia, Anatoly Zaitsev, claimed that 8,000 Georgian troops were massing at the border with Abkhazia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.regnum.ru/english/1046150.html |title=Georgian troops consolidated near Kodori Gorge |publisher=[[REGNUM News Agency|Regnum]] |date=25 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827212812/http://www.regnum.ru/english/1046150.html |archivedate=27 August 2008}}{{dead link|date=October 2015}}</ref>
Abkhaz and South Ossetian leaders addressed the Russian Parliament before the vote at extraordinary sittings, which had been formally convened by separatist appeals. Both houses of the Russian Parliament passed unanimous non-binding resolutions calling on Russian President Medvedev to recognise the independence of Abkhazia and South Ossetia. The US state department said that such action would be "a violation of Georgian territorial integrity" and "inconsistent with international law". American president Bush said, "I call on Russia's leadership to meet its commitments and not recognise these separatist regions." German, British and Italian leaders were also concerned.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7580386.stm|title=Russian MPs back Georgia's rebels|date=25 August 2008|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
=== August 26 ===
Russian President Medvedev signed two Presidential decrees recognizing the Republic of Abkhazia and the Republic of South Ossetia as sovereign independent states. He authorized the drafting of treaties of friendship, cooperation and mutual assistance with authorities in Sukhumi and Tskhinvali.<ref name="26 _August">{{cite web|url=http://www.undemocracy.com/securitycouncil/meeting_5969 |title=Security Council meeting 5969 | date=28 August 2008 |publisher=UNdemocracy |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913200224/http://www.undemocracy.com/securitycouncil/meeting_5969 |archivedate=13 September 2008}}{{dead link|date=October 2015}}</ref>
